utterances: We have about 300 people here in Philadelphia, 'cause we support the military all over the world.
But we do have probably 20 to 30 people that concentrate solely on Iraq and Afghanistan and the requirements for the military stationed there.
So this stuff is shipped from the U.S.
It takes about 75 days to get to Afghanistan and Iraq.

And I've read that in the past, you had to sort of negotiate some pretty hairy border crossings just to get the food into Afghanistan, for example, like dealing with tribal warlords on the borders and stuff.
Yes.
If you take the Pakistan route, it can take 12 days to travel from the Karachi port all the way up into Afghanistan.
And along the way, you might be asked to pay a little toll now and then.
Aha, yes.
And then, if you come in through the north, depending upon the weather you might get shut down because of snow or something like that.
The roads are just very narrow and can be completely impassable at times.
Some of these troops, particularly in Afghanistan, are in pretty remote outposts.
How do you get the food down to them?
There are some customers in Afghanistan where we routinely deliver by helicopter.
There is no way to get a truck into some of the remote areas that they have, and helicopter is the standard means of getting them food on a consistent basis.
What does it cost to feed 120,000 troops, or even just the troops in Afghanistan, this one Thanksgiving meal?
It's $7 per person per meal.
That's pretty good.
It seems pretty efficient.
Why don't you just do Thanksgiving everyday?
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
It would - believe it or not, is - you can only eat so much turkey.
So it would get mundane after a while.
The American military presence in Iraq, of course, is winding down.
And the 20,000 or so troops that are still there will be home by the end of December.
So this is probably the last Thanksgiving you're going to be coordinating for troops there, right?
Yes.
We'll be taking on the Department of State, who's going into Iraq to complete the mission.
Now normally, after Thanksgiving somebody like you would be able to just relax and kind of take it easy.
But you're like doing the same thing for Christmas just a few weeks later.
Yes, and the Christmas meal is already in Iraq and Afghanistan, poised to go out to the troops once Thanksgiving is over.
And it's pretty much the same meal except you throw in some eggnog, right?
Yeah, it is the same meal.
Yes.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
That's Rich Faso.
He's with the U.S.
Defense Logistics Agency.
He's the man in charge of getting a hot Thanksgiving meal and Christmas meal out to all American servicemen and women abroad.
Rich Faso, thanks so much.
Thank you, Guy.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
NPR's Sylvia Poggioli reports from Rome on Europe's response.
But while many European governments have since made U-turns, they're still slow to act.
Paddy Ashdown, former international envoy in Bosnia, said that, as in that country, military intervention should not be ruled out.
And, therefore, making contingencies for a no-fly zone is absolutely right, absolutely proper.
That isn't to say that it should happen now.
The thing that will determine this is not the military side but the politics.
But reactions on the continent were negative.
French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe said a NATO military action could be extremely counterproductive.
And his German counterpart, Guido Westerwelle, warned against meddling in Libya's affairs.
Italian political analyst Sergio Romano says Europe is reluctant to take part in another military action in a Muslim country.
When you say no-fly zone, it looks like you're doing something very humanitarian.
But it isn't neutral to be in a country where there is a civil war because sooner or later you find yourself fighting for something.
And as for sanctions, up to now, only Austria, Germany and Great Britain have agreed to freeze assets linked to the Gadhafi family.
Nothing has been done yet in Italy, where Gadhafi is one of the major foreign investors on the Italian stock market.
Jan Techau, Europe director of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, says Europe risks again pursuing only short-term solutions.
Traditionally, not only the Europeans but basically the entire West has always had to make that tough decision between democratization and stabilization.
But since short-term results are so much easier to measure than long-term results, my fear is that we will always politically, you know, be very prone to look at the short-term results.
Sylvia Poggioli, NPR News.
In the 104th Congress in 1995, there was several big changes.
The Contract with America pledged voluntary term limits, which some members even observed.
Gingrich gave the public new access to legislation through the Internet.
Suddenly, you could read bills online.
Political scientists Thomas Mann and Norman Ornstein have been watching Congress since the 1960s.
They've written a book together called "The Broken Branch: How Congress Is Failing America and How to Get it Back on Track.
Tom Mann says that sometimes taking over the House doesn't have a huge impact if your party was only briefly out of power and the new majority is a small one.
But neither of those things was the case back in 1995 when the changeover seemed epic.
New speaker, Newt Gingrich, acting like the modern-day Moses with his 10-step contract with America, parting the seas of the Potomac River and leading his troops up the steps of the Capitol.
It was a dramatic time, and certainly signified a significant shift in our politics.
And at the start, they really did make some changes to open the process up after the kind of forced march that they went through early on with the Contract with America.
Political scientist Norman Ornstein says the Republicans had hoped to make Congress the supreme branch.
Newt Gingrich got more attention than any congressional leader in history, really - became a household word and almost set himself up as a rival president.
It didn't last that long, however.
There's no way in which a Congress can become the supreme branch.
And in the end, a lot of the changes that they implemented to transform the Congress into an open body and a deliberative body, we're not only altered but reversed over time.
But, Norman Ornstein says, a sitting president whose party loses control of Congress and a new upstart majority can be effective.

Because all of a sudden, what you've got is a shotgun marriage between a Congress that is new in the majority and wants to stay there after two years and has to accomplish something, and a president who's either looking for re-election or looking for legacy.
For example, welfare reform in 1996 - tax reform under Ronald Reagan after the Republicans lost the Senate in 1986.
Tom Mann points out that there is a tension built into winning the majority.
With absolute party discipline, you can win all the votes.
You set the agenda, you have the committee chairs, you call the witnesses and you set the rules.
Mann and Ornstein say under Speaker Dennis Hastert, the Republican majority used the rules to turn the House into some place as partisan as Britain's House of Commons.
The only bills that could reach the floor were those approved by a majority of the majority.
Thomas Mann says over time, the Republican idealists of January 1995 started placing the will to win over respect for the rules of the Chamber.
The ends justify the means.

A conference process to reconcile differences between the House and the Senate is reduced to a handful of leaders working out deals in the dead of night, adding items after the report has been signed off, and then rushing it to a floor vote before anyone has a chance to read it.
Or, what happened at 3 a.m. one Saturday in 2003.
The Republican-led House voted on President Bush's Medicare bill.

After the standard 15 minutes, they came up just short of a majority so the leadership ignored the rules and held the vote open for almost three hours until they got a couple of skeptical Republicans to change their votes.
Then and only then, Speaker Dennis Hastert lowered the gavel.
Democrats, like Barney Frank of Massachusetts, could hardly believe what they were seeing.
Mr.
Speaker, parliamentarian inquiry.
After all the razzle-dazzle, exactly what was the prevailing side?
The ayes have it.
The second-ranking Democrat, Steny Hoyer of Maryland, protested to the speaker that the Democrats had really carried the day.
We have prevailed on this vote.
Arms have been twisted and votes changed.
(Soundbite of boo)
And I will continue to reserve.
